conclusion: To find the effective value of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil.
Magnetic flux through the coil is given by Φ = B ⋅ A ⋅ cos(θ).
B is the magnetic induction intensity, A is the area of the coil, θ is the angle between the magnetic field and the normal to the coil.
For a square coil with side length L, the area A is L^2.
The angle θ as a function of time t is θ = ωt.
Induced EMF in the coil is given by Faraday's Law: 𝓔 = -N dΦ/dt.
Substitute Φ = B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ cos(ωt) into the EMF equation.
Differentiate Φ with respect to time t: dΦ/dt = -B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω sin(ωt).
Substitute back into Faraday's Law: 𝓔 = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω sin(ωt).
The effective value (RMS value) of the induced EMF is 𝓔_rms = 𝓔_max/√2.
The maximum value of the induced EMF occurs when sin(ωt) = 1: 𝓔_max = N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω.
The effective value is 𝓔_rms = (N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω)/√2.
The effective value of the induced electromotive force in the coil is (N ⋅ B ⋅ L^2 ⋅ ω)/√2.
